text: how bill clinton went from signing the
Defense of Marriage Act in 1996 to
disavowing it today i'm rick burke for
the new york times Peter Baker covered
the Clinton White House and joins me now
from Washington now Peter you were there
that night you remember that night when
Clinton signed DOMA under the cover of
darkness tell me about it yeah it's
interesting to think about today
seventeen years later its front-page
news that Supreme Court takes up the
issue this week but back of the day it
was something Bill Clinton was trying to
keep under the rug he was he didn't
really like signing this bill a defined
under federal law marriage to be the
union of a man and woman and he felt
trapped by Republicans who were trying
to maneuver him into a bad position just
weeks before an election he'd been out
on the campaign trail for four days he
lands back at the White House under
under after dark heads to the Oval
Office and signs the bill at 12:50 a.m.
literally nobody knew that he had done
it the press sector gets a call home
saying should we announce her to wait
till the morning and I remember the next
morning we wrote the story it turned out
to be nine paragraphs in the next day's
newspaper if it still using the
theoretical political issue
Peter you fell into their trap of not
playing it up big as a story I did in a
way absolutely I mean at the time it
seemed like more of a theoretical issue
a political issue
it didn't seem like something that was
genuinely changing
you know law in the country in the sense
that no state at that time had same-sex
marriage so it seemed more but let's
think about this I mean I remember the
year F right after he got elected I
wrote a piece for The Times Magazine on
Bobcat toy the first openly gay man at
the White House he had all kinds of gay
friends from fund raisers from
California and so forth so wasn't the
gay community at the time surprised that
he did this or maybe not Oh what yeah
very surprised and very angry a lot of
people obviously it's that's what makes
it such an interesting story because
Bill Clinton was really the first
president to openly court the gay
community to openly embrace their
priorities he pushed for a workplace
non-discrimination law he had as you
pointed out openly gay advisors he
pushed for AIDS funding he tried to get
the military to open its doors to to the
yeas and lesbians didn't succeed got a
compromise that people didn't like
called Don't Ask Don't Tell so when this
came up it was it felt like a betrayal I
think to a lot of his friends who
considered an active calculation of
politics over principle I think he tried
to live with that for the next 17 years
but when you Peter when you talk about
him living with it and this is a purely
political pragmatic act reading your
piece today in The Times you say he
advised John Kerry to take the same
position when Kerry was running for
election so was he really in his heart
is it is your sense being pragmatic or
do you really think gays should not have
those that be able to get married well
first of all he denies the the report
about telling Kerry that in 2004 we
should point that out secondly I think
he's been conflicted I mean his position
was heading into 1996 was not in favor
of same-sex marriage and let's face it a
lot of you know
most politicians of that era were in the
same position he was not unique in that
regard very few even Democrats were for
same-sex marriage even civil unions
hadn't really come up as a widely
accepted idea so to him the calculation
was is it worth risking a second term
over vetoing a bill that had such large
margins both houses that they would have
been his veto would have been overridden
anyway but it has always been a conflict
with President Clinton in between
pragmatism and principle between
calculation and where his heart is so I
think I think he's struggled with those
issues over the years and and like many
Americans in the last few years has come
to see that his old position you know no
longer to him makes sense the way it
once did where does Hillary Clinton's
statement on the same issue fit into
this equation of course she came out
very quickly after President Clinton
repudiated DOMA this month and said she
too was for same-sex marriage she
explained she couldn't have said that
the last four years when she was still
in office as Secretary of State it
wouldn't have been appropriate for the
nation's top diplomat to weigh in on a
domestic issue and now she's come out
for it
people think that suggests that she's
obviously heading toward you know the
runway for a 2016 presidential let's not
get gone let's not get started with the
next presidential campaign just yet oh
come on we're already three months in
are you kidding but look you know I
think she would have said this whether
she's running for president anyway I
think that she you know felt that she
was you know trying to catch up to where
her party is and where her supporters
are so it doesn't necessarily tell us
anything about her ambitions do you is
it your sense that she worked on her
husband or that Chelsea had a role or
any of the other out gay friends of Bill
Clinton over the years had a role I
think clearly Chelsea like a lot of
families younger people have been more
open to same-sex marriage than the
parents and they have nudged them along
Chelsea came out for same-sex marriage
in New York the day before President
Clinton endorsed legislation there and I
think he's listening to his gay friends
and gay supporters going back years and
they've said to him why you want why you
on this side of the issue when you agree
with us on so many other
shoes and and he you know he sort of
inched his way over the last four years
especially closer and closer toward it
he he said on a rope line I'm not fool
I'm not against same-sex marriage any
more than he gives an interview to
Anderson Cooper then he comes out for
the New York legislation and finally
tapes robo calls in North Carolina last
year urging voters there to reject a
constitutional ban on on same-sex
marriage so he's kind of piece by piece
move closer toward the position where he
is today okay now a final question Peter
I want you to do a journalistic redo if
you could go back 17 years would you
rewrite that story and would you Lobby
it for it to be on page one oh
absolutely of course I you know I don't
think you know in my you know my mistake
at the time I think a lot of people's
mistake at the time was not to recognize
how significant an issue this really was
and how relevant and tangible it would
be in the years to come
you know again at that time nobody
nobody thought that it had any impact on
real lives one of President Linton's
aides said was you know why risk a
second term on something where nobody's
life will change the next day right
Peter thank you if that's such a pretty
quickly
thanks thanks much Peter I'm rich birth
in the New York Times
